summary: This is an email chain from August 2020 between personnel at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) and a contractor, discussing technical issues with a searchable PDF of a draft OPR report. The report concerns the Office of Professional Responsibility's investigation into the handling of the Jeffrey Epstein matter by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida from 2006-2008.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the draft OPR report being discussed, which investigates the handling of his case by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: Handling of Epstein Matter by SD Florida
events.description: The period under review by the Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) regarding how the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida handled the Jeffrey Epstein case.

events.title: OPR Draft Report Transmitted
events.description: The Office of Professional Responsibility transmits its draft report and a cover letter to the Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York for review.

events.title: Technical Issues with OPR Report PDF
events.description: Email correspondence reveals technical difficulties where the main body of the OPR draft report (over 370 pages) is not searchable via text, while the appendix is.

locations: U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York
U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida
Office of Professional Responsibility, U.S. Department of Justice, 930 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW â€” Room 3266, Washington, D.C. 20330
keyFacts: The Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) completed a draft report investigating the handling of the Jeffrey Epstein matter by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida during 2006-2008.
The draft OPR report was transmitted to the Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York on August 6, 2020, for review.
The document reveals internal technical problems where the PDF of the draft report was not fully text-searchable, hindering review.
The correspondence confirms an ongoing internal DOJ review of prosecutorial conduct in the early Epstein case years after the 2019 case brought by SDNY.
